text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with boneless baby back ribs

sandwich that's Mick right this
incredibly amazing sandwich is inspired

by the McRib and while there are some
similarities there's also some big

differences for example this is actually
made with pork ribs while the fast-food

franchise version is made with specially
molded mystery meat and if you're

thinking hey I like that specially
molded mystery meat well then in that

case you are absolutely gonna love this
since this really was one of the best

sandwiches I've ever had so with that
let's go ahead and get started and first

up we'll place a couple racks of baby
back ribs on a foil lined baking sheet

and sometimes we actually peel off the
membrane that's on the underside but

this time we're not going to because
that's gonna help hold things together

later and what we're gonna have to do
here is seasoned this very generously on

both sides with the dry rub of our
choice which as you know is a mixture of

salt sugar and spices and of course I
would give you the measurements of what

I used on the block but having said that
I don't think I've ever used the same

dry rub twice so how exactly you season
these is gonna be up to you I mean you

guys are after all the Barry Gibbs of
making very good ribs and speaking of

stayin alive if for the sake of argument
your dry rub has nine ingredients which

is a lot and you include the pork your
boneless rib sandwich will have

literally sixty less ingredients than
the fast food version which is a fun but

very horrifying fact but anyway once
those racks are seasoned

I like to top them with a piece of
parchment paper although that is

optional but I do feel like it provides
sort of a protective membrane and then

what we'll do is bring that foil in from
around the outside around the outside

around the outside
at which point we'll cover everything

with one large piece of foil and seal
that up nice and tightly around the

edges and once that set it is now ready
to transfer into the center of a 325

degree oven for exactly 2 hours and 45
minutes or however long it takes for our

meat to become tender enough so that we
can easily pull out the bones since that

really is the key to this whole
operation so after 2 and 3/4 hours I

pulled my doubts and went ahead and
carefully unwrapped it and once

unwrapped what we'll do is very very
carefully flip these over

and proceed to push and slide out those
bones which if these have cooked long

enough is going to be very very easy and
by the way well we want these tender

enough so we can do the next step if you
cook them so tender that they're falling

apart it's gonna make it very very
difficult to work with on the grill so

be careful not to cook these too far but
anyway like I said we'll go ahead and

slide out those bones although these
were too hot and I was burning my

fingers so you really do want to let
them cool down a little bit and by the

way if any pieces of meat or bone marrow
fall out just shove that right back in

one of the holes so I did let those sit
and cool down for a few minutes before

continuing on and above and beyond
pulling those bones out which is gonna

be very easy we also have to be
extremely careful we're also pulling out

any small pieces of bone or pieces of
cartilage left behind okay there's one

right there
and depending on how your racks were cut

that might just be a couple pieces or a
whole bunch of pieces so you really want

to make sure you very carefully and
thoughtfully feel along all those edges

so that once you're done you have
nothing left but pure meat otherwise you

might have problems and by problems I
mean lawsuits so that's something we

will double and triple check before
anyone eats these speaking of which if

you had to eat these now I guess you
could paint in with barbecue sauce

and finish them on the grill but I think
this works much much better if we wrap

these back up and refrigerate them until
nice and cold which I actually did

overnight so yes this is something you
could prep the day before the cookout

and I just think that cold for me makes
everything easier to work with plus if

we sauce these and put them on the grill
cold that'll give us more time to glaze

that barbecue sauce on before the inside
the rib heats through too much and

starts falling apart so like I said I
did pop mine in the fridge overnight at

which point we'll go ahead and pull
those out unwrap them and cut them in

half because I'm going to be doing half
a rack per sandwich although if you're

gonna use smaller hamburger buns for
these you could probably get four

portions per rack Bob regardless of how
many portions you do before these go on

the grill we want to brush them very
generously on both sides with the

barbecue sauce of our choice and today
I'll be using a little something called

sfq which as you may or may not know is
something my wife Michelle and I make

but whatever your favorite barbecue
sauce is will work

unless it's like one of those really
cheap ons with the high-fructose corn

syrup in that case you should probably
use something a little better or maybe

even whip up a batch of your own but
regardless we're gonna want to brush

that generously on both sides at which
point we are ready to grab our tongs and

head outside to finish these on the
grill preferably over some nice hot

smokey coals and since these are already
cooked they're only gonna take like

three or four minutes per side okay all
we're doing here is searing on that

sauce and heating these through and if
we cook them too long they might start

to fall apart so I gave that first side
about three or four minutes and that

very carefully flip them over and
hopefully not too much sticks but if you

do get some superficial abrasions
well of course hide those by brushing on

a little extra sauce oh and I should
probably also mention if you know your

way around a smoker you could totally
skip that oven step and just smoke these

low and slow the day before which is
probably not a bad idea if it's really

hot and you don't want the oven on in
the house but either way they're gonna

get finished like this and then once we
feel like those have been grilled enough

and that meats been heated through we'll
go ahead and carefully pull them off

along with any delicious scraps and we
will head back inside and then while

these are still hot I always like to
brush on a little extra sauce just to

sort of shine him up at which point
that's ready to transfer out to whatever

bread or roll we're using which for me
were some rectangular shape rolls that I

made using our famous hamburger bun
recipe and as you can see I'm squirting

on a little extra sauce before I lay in
the meat down and by the way because I

just guessed it the size of the roll I
needed I'm breaking one of the cardinal

rules of barbecued meat sandwiches that
states that the meat must be as big or

bigger than the roll and as you can see
I was a little bit short but anyway I

went ahead and topped that with even
more sauce as well as a nice pile of our

hot and sweet mustard slaw and we'll go
ahead and top that with the other half

of our roll and that is looking just
about perfect except for that empty spot

at the end that I'm about to food style
away with a piece of rib eye slice from

the other rack oh yeah that's better but
anyway I took a few pictures and then

grabbed this with both hands and went in
for a taste

and that my friends really was one of
the best sandwiches I've ever eaten okay

I absolutely love baby back ribs and
really have no problem eating them off

the bone but to be able to enjoy it on
this roll with no bones and just totally

luxuriate in the experience really was
something special and even though these

weren't over the coals that long
they really do pick up a nice amount of

smokiness which of course adds to the
whole experience but anyway that's it

where we're calling a boneless baby back
rib sandwich with this lacks in like

over 60 ingredients it more than makes
up for by being actual meat and not a

bunch of glued together scraps and it
really is a very simple and easy

technique to pull off so whether you're
gonna make this to really impress dad on

Father's Day or any other time you're
gonna have the grill fired up in the

backyard I really do hope you give this
a try soon so head over to food wishes

dot-com for all the ingredient amounts
of more info as usual and as always
you
you
